t: Luke 1
The Dedication to Theophilus
Many*p have undertaken to compile a narrative about the events that have been fulfilled among us,
just as the original eyewitnesses and servants of the word handed them down to us.
So it also seemed good to me, since I have carefully investigated everything from the very first, to write to you in an orderly sequence, most honorable Theophilus,
so that you may know the certainty of the things about which you have been instructed.
Gabriel Predicts John’s Birth
In*p the days of King Herod of Judea, there was a priest of Abijah’s division named Zechariah. His wife was from the daughters of Aaron, and her name was Elizabeth.
Both were righteous in God’s sight, living without blame according to all the commands and requirements of the Lord.
But they had no children because Elizabeth could not conceive, and both of them were well along in years.
When*p his division was on duty and he was serving as priest before God,
it happened that he was chosen by lot, according to the custom of the priesthood, to enter the sanctuary of the Lord and burn incense.
At the hour of incense the whole assembly of the people was praying outside.
An angel of the Lord appeared to him, standing to the right of the altar of incense.
When Zechariah saw him, he was terrified and overcome with fear.
But the angel said to him, “Do not be afraid, Zechariah, because your prayer has been heard. Your wife Elizabeth will bear you a son, and you will name him John.
There will be joy and delight for you, and many will rejoice at his birth.
For he will be great in the sight of the Lord and will never drink wine or beer. He will be filled with the Holy Spirit while still in his mother’s womb.
He will turn many of the children of Israel to the Lord their God.

And he will go before him in the spirit and power of Elijah, to turn the hearts of fathers to their children, and the disobedient to the understanding of the righteous, to make ready for the Lord a prepared people.”
“How*p can I know this?” Zechariah asked the angel. “For I am an old man, and my wife is well along in years.”
The*p angel answered him, “I am Gabriel, who stands in the presence of God, and I was sent to speak to you and tell you this good news.
Now listen. You will become silent and unable to speak until the day these things take place, because you did not believe my words, which will be fulfilled in their proper time.”
Meanwhile,*p the people were waiting for Zechariah, amazed that he stayed so long in the sanctuary.
When he did come out, he could not speak to them. Then they realized that he had seen a vision in the sanctuary. He was making signs to them and remained speechless.
When the days of his ministry were completed, he went back home.
After*p these days his wife Elizabeth conceived and kept herself in seclusion for five months. She said,
“The Lord has done this for me. He has looked with favor in these days to take away my disgrace among the people.”
Gabriel Predicts Jesus’s Birth
In*p the sixth month, the angel Gabriel was sent by God to a town in Galilee called Nazareth,
to a virgin engaged to a man named Joseph, of the house of David. The virgin’s name was Mary.
And the angel came to her and said, “Greetings, favored woman! The Lord is with you.”
But she was deeply troubled by this statement, wondering what kind of greeting this could be.
Then the angel told her, “Do not be afraid, Mary, for you have found favor with God.
Now listen: You will conceive and give birth to a son, and you will name him Jesus.
He will be great and will be called the Son of the Most High, and the Lord God will give him the throne of his father David.
He will reign over the house of Jacob forever, and his kingdom will have no end.”
Mary*p asked the angel, “How can this be, since I have not had sexual relations with a man?”
The*p angel replied to her, “The Holy Spirit will come upon you, and the power of the Most High will overshadow you. Therefore, the holy one to be born will be called the Son of God.
And consider your relative Elizabeth - even she has conceived a son in her old age, and this is the sixth month for her who was called childless.
For nothing will be impossible with God.”
“See,*p I am the Lord’s servant,” said Mary. “May it happen to me as you have said.” Then the angel left her.
Mary’s Visit to Elizabeth
In*p those days Mary set out and hurried to a town in the hill country of Judah
where she entered Zechariah’s house and greeted Elizabeth.
When Elizabeth heard Mary’s greeting, the baby leaped inside her, and Elizabeth was filled with the Holy Spirit.
Then she exclaimed with a loud cry, “Blessed are you among women, and your child will be blessed!
How could this happen to me, that the mother of my Lord should come to me?
For you see, when the sound of your greeting reached my ears, the baby leaped for joy inside me.
Blessed is she who has believed that the Lord would fulfill what he has spoken to her!”
Mary’s Praise
And*p Mary said: My*pn soul magnifies the Lord,
and*ln my spirit rejoices in God my Savior,
because*ln he has looked with favor on*ln the humble condition of his servant. Surely,*ln from now on all generations will*ln call me blessed,
because*ln the Mighty One has*ln done great things for me, and*ln his name is holy.
His*ln mercy is from generation to generation on*ln those who fear him.
He*ln has done a mighty deed with his arm; he*ln has scattered the proud because*ln of the thoughts of their hearts;
he*ln has toppled the mighty from their thrones and*ln exalted the lowly.
He*ln has satisfied the hungry with good things and*ln sent the rich away empty.
He*ln has helped his servant Israel, remembering*ln his mercy
to*ln Abraham and his descendants forever, just*ln as he spoke to our ancestors.
And*p Mary stayed with her about three months; then she returned to her home.
The Birth and Naming of John
Now*p the time had come for Elizabeth to give birth, and she had a son.
Then her neighbors and relatives heard that the Lord had shown her his great mercy, and they rejoiced with her.
When*p they came to circumcise the child on the eighth day, they were going to name him Zechariah, after his father.
But his mother responded, “No. He will be called John.”
Then*p they said to her, “None of your relatives has that name.”
So they motioned to his father to find out what he wanted him to be called.
He asked for a writing tablet and wrote, “His name is John.” And they were all amazed.
Immediately his mouth was opened and his tongue set free, and he began to speak, praising God.
Fear came on all those who lived around them, and all these things were being talked about throughout the hill country of Judea.
All who heard about him took it to heart, saying, “What then will this child become?” For, indeed, the Lord’s hand was with him.
Zechariah’s Prophecy
Then*p his father Zechariah was filled with the Holy Spirit and prophesied:
Blessed*pn is the Lord, the God of Israel, because*ln he has visited and*ln provided redemption for his people.
He*ln has raised up a horn of salvation for us in*ln the house of his servant David,
just*ln as he spoke by the mouth of*ln his holy prophets in ancient times;
salvation*ln from our enemies and*ln from the hand of those who hate us.
He*ln has dealt mercifully with our ancestors and*ln remembered his holy covenant—
the*ln oath that he swore to our father Abraham, to*ln grant that we,
having*ln been rescued from*ln the hand of our enemies, would*ln serve him without fear
in*ln holiness and righteousness in*ln his presence all our days.
And*ln you, child, will be called a*ln prophet of the Most High, for*ln you will go before the Lord to*ln prepare his ways,
to*ln give his people knowledge of salvation through*ln the forgiveness of their sins.
Because*ln of our God’s merciful compassion, the*ln dawn from on high will visit us
to*ln shine on those who live in darkness and*ln the shadow of death, to*ln guide our feet into the way of peace.
The*p child grew up and became strong in spirit, and he was in the wilderness until the day of his public appearance to Israel.
Luke 2
The Birth of Jesus
In*p those days a decree went out from Caesar Augustus that the whole empire should be registered.
This first registration took place while Quirinius was governing Syria.
So everyone went to be registered, each to his own town.
Joseph*p also went up from the town of Nazareth in Galilee, to Judea, to the city of David, which is called Bethlehem, because he was of the house and family line of David,
to be registered along with Mary, who was engaged to him and was pregnant.
While they were there, the time came for her to give birth.
Then she gave birth to her firstborn son, and she wrapped him tightly in cloth and laid him in a manger, because there was no guest room available for them.
The Shepherds and the Angels
In*p the same region, shepherds were staying out in the fields and keeping watch at night over their flock.
Then an angel of the Lord stood before them, and the glory of the Lord shone around them, and they were terrified.
But the angel said to them, “Don’t be afraid, for look, I proclaim to you good news of great joy that will be for all the people:
Today in the city of David a Savior was born for you, who is the Messiah, the Lord.
This will be the sign for you: You will find a baby wrapped tightly in cloth and lying in a manger.”
Suddenly*p there was a multitude of the heavenly host with the angel, praising God and saying:
Glory*pn to God in the highest heaven, and*ln peace on earth to people he favors!
When*p the angels had left them and returned to heaven, the shepherds said to one another, “Let’s go straight to Bethlehem and see what has happened, which the Lord has made known to us.”
They*p hurried off and found both Mary and Joseph, and the baby who was lying in the manger.
After seeing them, they reported the message they were told about this child,
and all who heard it were amazed at what the shepherds said to them.
But Mary was treasuring up all these things in her heart and meditating on them.
The shepherds returned, glorifying and praising God for all the things they had seen and heard, which were just as they had been told.
The Circumcision and Presentation of Jesus
When*p the eight days were completed for his circumcision, he was named Jesus- the name given by the angel before he was conceived.
And when the days of their purification according to the law of Moses were finished, they brought him up to Jerusalem to present him to the Lord
(just as it is written in the law of the Lord, Every*i firstborn*i male*i will*i be*i dedicated*i to*i the*i Lord)*i
and to offer a sacrifice (according to what is stated in the law of the Lord, a*i pair*i of*i turtledoves*i or*i two*i young*i pigeons).*i
Simeon’s Prophetic Praise
There*p was a man in Jerusalem whose name was Simeon. This man was righteous and devout, looking forward to Israel’s consolation, and the Holy Spirit was on him.
It had been revealed to him by the Holy Spirit that he would not see death before he saw the Lord’s Messiah.
Guided by the Spirit, he entered the temple. When the parents brought in the child Jesus to perform for him what was customary under the law,
Simeon took him up in his arms, praised God, and said,
Now,*pn Master, you*ln can dismiss your servant in peace, as*ln you promised.
For*ln my eyes have seen your salvation.
You*ln have prepared it in*ln the presence of all peoples —
a*ln light for revelation to the Gentiles and*ln glory to your people Israel.
His*p father and mother were amazed at what was being said about him.
Then Simeon blessed them and told his mother Mary, “Indeed, this child is destined to cause the fall and rise of many in Israel and to be a sign that will be opposed-
and a sword will pierce your own soul - that the thoughts of many hearts may be revealed.”
Anna’s Testimony
There*p was also a prophetess, Anna, a daughter of Phanuel, of the tribe of Asher. She was well along in years, having lived with her husband seven years after her marriage,
and was a widow for eighty-four years. She did not leave the temple, serving God night and day with fasting and prayers.
At that very moment, she came up and began to thank God and to speak about him to all who were looking forward to the redemption of Jerusalem.
The Family’s Return to Nazareth
When*p they had completed everything according to the law of the Lord, they returned to Galilee, to their own town of Nazareth.
The boy grew up and became strong, filled with wisdom, and God’s grace was on him.
In His Father’s House
Every*p year his parents traveled to Jerusalem for the Passover Festival.
When he was twelve years old, they went up according to the custom of the festival.
After those days were over, as they were returning, the boy Jesus stayed behind in Jerusalem, but his parents did not know it.
Assuming he was in the traveling party, they went a day’s journey. Then they began looking for him among their relatives and friends.
When they did not find him, they returned to Jerusalem to search for him.
After three days, they found him in the temple sitting among the teachers, listening to them and asking them questions.
And all those who heard him were astounded at his understanding and his answers.
When his parents saw him, they were astonished, and his mother said to him, “Son, why have you treated us like this? Your father and I have been anxiously searching for you.”
“Why*rp were*r you*r searching*r for*r me?”*r he asked them. “Didn’t*r you*r know*r that*r it*r was*r necessary*r for*r me*r to*r be*r in*r my*r Father’s*r house?”*r
But they did not understand what he said to them.
In Favor with God and with People
Then*p he went down with them and came to Nazareth and was obedient to them. His mother kept all these things in her heart.
And Jesus increased in wisdom and stature, and in favor with God and with people.
Luke 3
The Messiah’s Herald

In*p the fifteenth year of the reign of Tiberius Caesar, while Pontius Pilate was governor of Judea, Herod was tetrarch of Galilee, his brother Philip tetrarch of the region of Iturea and Trachonitis, and Lysanias tetrarch of Abilene,
during the high priesthood of Annas and Caiaphas, God’s word came to John the son of Zechariah in the wilderness.
He went into all the vicinity of the Jordan, proclaiming a baptism of repentance for the forgiveness of sins,

as it is written in the book of the words of the prophet Isaiah: A*ipn voice*i of*i one*i crying*i out*i in*i the*i wilderness:*i Prepare*iln the*i way*i for*i the*i Lord;*i make*iln his*i paths*i straight!*i
Every*iln valley*i will*i be*i filled,*i and*iln every*i mountain*i and*i hill*i will*i be*i made*i low;*i the*iln crooked*i will*i become*i straight,*i the*iln rough*i ways*i smooth,*i
and*iln everyone*i will*i see*i the*i salvation*i of*i God.*i
He*p then said to the crowds who came out to be baptized by him, “Brood of vipers! Who warned you to flee from the coming wrath?

Therefore produce fruit consistent with repentance. And don’t start saying to yourselves, ‘We have Abraham as our father,’ for I tell you that God is able to raise up children for Abraham from these stones.
The ax is already at the root of the trees. Therefore, every tree that doesn’t produce good fruit will be cut down and thrown into the fire.”
“What*p then should we do?” the crowds were asking him.
He*p replied to them, “The one who has two shirts must share with someone who has none, and the one who has food must do the same.”
Tax*p collectors also came to be baptized, and they asked him, “Teacher, what should we do?”
He*p told them, “Don’t collect any more than what you have been authorized.”
Some*p soldiers also questioned him, “What should we do?” He*p said to them, “Don’t take money from anyone by force or false accusation, and be satisfied with your wages.”
Now*p the people were waiting expectantly, and all of them were questioning in their hearts whether John might be the Messiah.

John answered them all, “I baptize you with water, but one who is more powerful than I am is coming. I am not worthy to untie the strap of his sandals. He will baptize you with the Holy Spirit and fire.
His winnowing shovel is in his hand to clear his threshing floor and gather the wheat into his barn, but the chaff he will burn with fire that never goes out.”
Then, along with many other exhortations, he proclaimed good news to the people.
But when John rebuked Herod the tetrarch because of Herodias, his brother’s wife, and all the evil things he had done,
Herod added this to everything else - he locked up John in prison.
The Baptism of Jesus
When*p all the people were baptized, Jesus also was baptized. As he was praying, heaven opened,
and the Holy Spirit descended on him in a physical appearance like a dove. And a voice came from heaven: “You are my beloved Son; with you I am well-pleased.”
The Genealogy of Jesus Christ
As*p he began his ministry, Jesus was about thirty years old and was thought to be the son*ln of Joseph, son of Heli,
son*ln of Matthat, son of Levi, son*ln of Melchi, son of Jannai, son*ln of Joseph,
son of Mattathias, son*ln of Amos, son of Nahum, son*ln of Esli, son of Naggai,
son*ln of Maath, son of Mattathias, son*ln of Semein, son of Josech, son*ln of Joda,
son of Joanan, son*ln of Rhesa, son of Zerubbabel, son*ln of Shealtiel, son of Neri,
son*ln of Melchi, son of Addi, son*ln of Cosam, son of Elmadam, son*ln of Er,
son of Joshua, son*ln of Eliezer, son of Jorim, son*ln of Matthat, son of Levi,
son*ln of Simeon, son of Judah, son*ln of Joseph, son of Jonam, son*ln of Eliakim,
son of Melea, son*ln of Menna, son of Mattatha, son*ln of Nathan, son of David,
son*ln of Jesse, son of Obed, son*ln of Boaz, son of Salmon, son*ln of Nahshon,
son of Amminadab, son*ln of Ram, son of Hezron, son*ln of Perez, son of Judah,
son*ln of Jacob, son of Isaac, son*ln of Abraham, son of Terah, son*ln of Nahor,
son of Serug, son*ln of Reu, son of Peleg, son*ln of Eber, son of Shelah,
son*ln of Cainan, son of Arphaxad, son*ln of Shem, son of Noah, son*ln of Lamech,
son of Methuselah, son*ln of Enoch, son of Jared, son*ln of Mahalalel, son of Cainan,
son*ln of Enos, son of Seth, son*ln of Adam, son of God.
Luke 4
The Temptation of Jesus
Then*p Jesus left the Jordan, full of the Holy Spirit, and was led by the Spirit in the wilderness
for forty days to be tempted by the devil. He ate nothing during those days, and when they were over, he was hungry.
The devil said to him, “If you are the Son of God, tell this stone to become bread.”
But*p Jesus answered him, “It*r is*r written:*r Man*ir must*ir not*ir live*ir on*ir bread*ir alone.”*ir
So*p he took him up and showed him all the kingdoms of the world in a moment of time.
The devil said to him, “I will give you their splendor and all this authority, because it has been given over to me, and I can give it to anyone I want.
If you, then, will worship me, all will be yours.”
And*p Jesus answered him, “It*r is*r written:*r Worship*ir the*ir Lord*ir your*ir God,*ir and*ir serve*ir him*ir only.”*ir
So*p he took him to Jerusalem, had him stand on the pinnacle of the temple, and said to him, “If you are the Son of God, throw yourself down from here.
For it is written: He*ipn will*i give*i his*i angels*i orders*i concerning*i you,*i to*iln protect*i you,*i
and they*iln will*i support*i you*i with*i their*i hands,*i so*iln that*i you*i will*i not*i strike*i your*iln foot*i against*i a*i stone.”*i
And*p Jesus answered him, “It*r is*r said:*r Do*ir not*ir test*ir the*ir Lord*ir your*ir God.”*ir
After*p the devil had finished every temptation, he departed from him for a time.
Ministry in Galilee
Then*p Jesus returned to Galilee in the power of the Spirit, and news about him spread throughout the entire vicinity.
He was teaching in their synagogues, being praised by everyone.
Rejection at Nazareth
He*p came to Nazareth, where he had been brought up. As usual, he entered the synagogue on the Sabbath day and stood up to read.
The scroll of the prophet Isaiah was given to him, and unrolling the scroll, he found the place where it was written:

The*irpn Spirit*ir of*ir the*ir Lord*ir is*ir on*ir me,*ir because*irln he*ir has*ir anointed*ir me*ir to*irln preach*ir good*ir news*ir to*ir the*ir poor.*ir He*irln has*ir sent*ir me*ir to*irln proclaim*ir release*ir to*ir the*ir captives*ir and*irln recovery*ir of*ir sight*ir to*ir the*ir blind,*ir to*irln set*ir free*ir the*ir oppressed,*ir
to*irln proclaim*ir the*ir year*ir of*ir the*ir Lord’s*ir favor.*ir
He*p then rolled up the scroll, gave it back to the attendant, and sat down. And the eyes of everyone in the synagogue were fixed on him.
He began by saying to them, “Today*r as*r you*r listen,*r this*r Scripture*r has*r been*r fulfilled.”*r
They*p were all speaking well of him and were amazed by the gracious words that came from his mouth; yet they said, “Isn’t this Joseph’s son?”

Then*p he said to them, “No*r doubt*r you*r will*r quote*r this*r proverb*r to*r me:*r ‘Doctor,*r heal*r yourself.*r What*r we’ve*r heard*r that*r took*r place*r in*r Capernaum,*r do*r here*r in*r your*r hometown*r also.’”*r
He*p also said, “Truly*r I*r tell*r you,*r no*r prophet*r is*r accepted*r in*r his*r hometown.*r

But*r I*r say*r to*r you,*r there*r were*r certainly*r many*r widows*r in*r Israel*r in*r Elijah’s*r days,*r when*r the*r sky*r was*r shut*r up*r for*r three*r years*r and*r six*r months*r while*r a*r great*r famine*r came*r over*r all*r the*r land.*r
Yet*r Elijah*r was*r not*r sent*r to*r any*r of*r them*r except*r a*r widow*r at*r Zarephath*r in*r Sidon.*r
And*r in*r the*r prophet*r Elisha’s*r time,*r there*r were*r many*r in*r Israel*r who*r had*r leprosy,*r and*r yet*r not*r one*r of*r them*r was*r cleansed*r except*r Naaman*r the*r Syrian.”*r
When*p they heard this, everyone in the synagogue was enraged.
They got up, drove him out of town, and brought him to the edge of the hill that their town was built on, intending to hurl him over the cliff.
But he passed right through the crowd and went on his way.
Driving Out an Unclean Spirit
Then*p he went down to Capernaum, a town in Galilee, and was teaching them on the Sabbath.
They were astonished at his teaching because his message had authority.
In the synagogue there was a man with an unclean demonic spirit who cried out with a loud voice,
“Leave us alone! What do you have to do with us, Jesus of Nazareth? Have you come to destroy us? I know who you are - the Holy One of God!”
But*p Jesus rebuked him and said, “Be*r silent*r and*r come*r out*r of*r him!”*r And throwing him down before them, the demon came out of him without hurting him at all.
Amazement*p came over them all, and they were saying to one another, “What is this message? For he commands the unclean spirits with authority and power, and they come out!”
And news about him began to go out to every place in the vicinity.
Healings at Capernaum
After*p he left the synagogue, he entered Simon’s house. Simon’s mother-in-law was suffering from a high fever, and they asked him about her.
So he stood over her and rebuked the fever, and it left her. She got up immediately and began to serve them.
When*p the sun was setting, all those who had anyone sick with various diseases brought them to him. As he laid his hands on each one of them, he healed them.
Also, demons were coming out of many, shouting and saying, “You are the Son of God!” But he rebuked them and would not allow them to speak, because they knew he was the Messiah.
When*p it was day, he went out and made his way to a deserted place. But the crowds were searching for him. They came to him and tried to keep him from leaving them.

But he said to them, “It*r is*r necessary*r for*r me*r to*r proclaim*r the*r good*r news*r about*r the*r kingdom*r of*r God*r to*r the*r other*r towns*r also,*r because*r I*r was*r sent*r for*r this*r purpose.”*r
And he was preaching in the synagogues of Judea.
Luke 5
The First Disciples
As*p the crowd was pressing in on Jesus to hear God’s word, he was standing by Lake Gennesaret.
He saw two boats at the edge of the lake; the fishermen had left them and were washing their nets.
He got into one of the boats, which belonged to Simon, and asked him to put out a little from the land. Then he sat down and was teaching the crowds from the boat.
When*p he had finished speaking, he said to Simon, “Put*r out*r into*r deep*r water*r and*r let*r down*r your*r nets*r for*r a*r catch.”*r
“Master,”*p Simon replied, “we’ve worked hard all night long and caught nothing. But if you say so, I’ll let down the nets.”
When*p they did this, they caught a great number of fish, and their nets began to tear.
So they signaled to their partners in the other boat to come and help them; they came and filled both boats so full that they began to sink.
When*p Simon Peter saw this, he fell at Jesus’s knees and said, “Go away from me, because I’m a sinful man, Lord!”
For he and all those with him were amazed at the catch of fish they had taken,
and so were James and John, Zebedee’s sons, who were Simon’s partners. “Don’t*rp be*r afraid,”*r Jesus told Simon. “From*r now*r on*r you*r will*r be*r catching*r people.”*r
Then they brought the boats to land, left everything, and followed him.
A Man Cleansed
While*p he was in one of the towns, a man was there who had leprosy all over him. He saw Jesus, fell facedown, and begged him, “Lord, if you are willing, you can make me clean.”
Reaching*p out his hand, Jesus touched him, saying, “I*r am*r willing;*r be*r made*r clean,”*r and immediately the leprosy left him.
Then he ordered him to tell no one: “But*r go*r and*r show*r yourself*r to*r the*r priest,*r and*r offer*r what*r Moses*r commanded*r for*r your*r cleansing*r as*r a*r testimony*r to*r them.”*r
But*p the news about him spread even more, and large crowds would come together to hear him and to be healed of their sicknesses.
Yet he often withdrew to deserted places and prayed.
The Son of Man Forgives and Heals

On*p one of those days while he was teaching, Pharisees and teachers of the law were sitting there who had come from every village of Galilee and Judea, and also from Jerusalem. And the Lord’s power to heal was in him.
Just then some men came, carrying on a stretcher a man who was paralyzed. They tried to bring him in and set him down before him.
Since they could not find a way to bring him in because of the crowd, they went up on the roof and lowered him on the stretcher through the roof tiles into the middle of the crowd before Jesus.
Seeing*p their faith he said, “Friend,*r your*r sins*r are*r forgiven.”*r
Then*p the scribes and the Pharisees began to think to themselves, “Who is this man who speaks blasphemies? Who can forgive sins but God alone?”
But*p perceiving their thoughts, Jesus replied to them, “Why*r are*r you*r thinking*r this*r in*r your*r hearts?*r
Which*r is*r easier:*r to*r say,*r ‘Your*r sins*r are*r forgiven,’*r or*r to*r say,*r ‘Get*r up*r and*r walk’?*r

But*r so*r that*r you*r may*r know*r that*r the*r Son*r of*r Man*r has*r authority*r on*r earth*r to*r forgive*r sins”-*r he told the paralyzed man, “I*r tell*r you:*r Get*r up,*r take*r your*r stretcher,*r and*r go*r home.”*r
Immediately*p he got up before them, picked up what he had been lying on, and went home glorifying God.
Then everyone was astounded, and they were giving glory to God. And they were filled with awe and said, “We have seen incredible things today.”
The Call of Levi
After*p this, Jesus went out and saw a tax collector named Levi sitting at the tax office, and he said to him, “Follow*r me.”*r
So, leaving everything behind, he got up and began to follow him.
Then*p Levi hosted a grand banquet for him at his house. Now there was a large crowd of tax collectors and others who were reclining at the table with them.
